headline: The U.S. and Ivy League schools were late to respond to COVID-19. Data shows international universities did better.
byline: By Kelly Pu, Jun Yi Zhang, Stephanie Lai, Raeedah Wahid Produced by Hong Sen Du and Jason Kao Edited by Karen Xia

top.value: In the wake of the COVID-19 coronavirus pandemic, university administrators and government officials across the world acted to curb the effects of the virus on student populations, evacuating thousands of students from campus and shifting to online courses in a matter of weeks.

steps: In the wake of the COVID-19 coronavirus pandemic, university administrators and government officials across the world acted to curb the effects of the virus on student populations, evacuating thousands of students from campus and shifting to online courses in a matter of weeks.
Harvard, Cornell, and Yale were the first Ivies to respond to the coronavirus outbreak by announcing mandatory move-out for students when there were 959 cases nationally.
Columbia University was the last Ivy to announce mandatory move-out, five days after the first Ivies. [ Quadruple TK ]
On average, the Ivy League universities took 8.375 days to respond after the first hundred reported cases in the nation.

This response rate equaled that of <c>China</c>, the first country to begin experiencing an outbreak in late January. 8 days after the first hundred reported cases, when the national number of cases had reached 2,863, the government mandated the closure of all schools.

The Iviesâ€™ responses were far slower than that of <c>South Korea</c>, which began experiencing an outbreak in late February. The South Korean government closed schools across the country when there were 602 cases, 2 days after the first hundred reported cases.
